questions.question: Prior to Pasteur, the prevailing scientific theory of how life arose from non-living matter was known as:
Pasteur’s Germ Theory proposed that:
options: a) All diseases are caused by viruses.
b) Specific microorganisms cause specific diseases.
c) Spontaneous generation is how microbes are created.
d) Sickness is caused by an imbalance of the body's humors.
questions.correctAnswer: b) Specific microorganisms cause specific diseases.

questions.question: What was the significance of the swan-neck flask in Pasteur’s experiments?
options: a) It allowed microbes to enter the broth but prevented air from reaching it.
b) It prevented microbes from reaching the broth while still allowing air to enter.
c) It trapped all gases inside the flask.
d) It allowed light to pass through the broth without interference.
questions.correctAnswer: b) It prevented microbes from reaching the broth while still allowing air to enter.

questions.question: Pasteurization is a process that involves:
options: a) Boiling a liquid to sterilize it completely.
b) Heating a liquid to a specific temperature for a set time to kill pathogens.
c) Freezing liquids to preserve them indefinitely.
d) Adding preservatives to prevent microbial growth.
questions.correctAnswer: b) Heating a liquid to a specific temperature for a set time to kill pathogens.

questions.question: Which disease was first vaccinated against by Pasteur in animals?
What does the Germ Theory of disease state?
options: a) Microbes spontaneously appear in sick organisms.
b) Specific microorganisms cause specific diseases.
c) Germs are always beneficial to humans.
d) Diseases are caused by bad air.
questions.correctAnswer: b) Specific microorganisms cause specific diseases.

questions.question: Which of the following best defines a microbe?
options: b) A microorganism too small to be seen without a microscope
c) Any germ that causes disease
d) Only bacteria that live in humans
questions.correctAnswer: b) A microorganism too small to be seen without a microscope
